title: Case Study: Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease in a 35-Year-Old Male
clinical_history: A 35-year-old male, who works as an IT specialist, presented with a 5-year history of progressive weakness and atrophy in his lower extremities. He reported difficulty walking and frequent tripping over his own feet. The patient also complained of numbness and tingling sensations in his feet and legs. He has a family history of similar symptoms, with his father and grandfather experiencing similar issues.

nprs.affected_area: Bilateral foot and ankle pain, described as burning and aching
Intermittent sharp pain in the lower legs, particularly during physical activity

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged standing, walking, or running; high-impact activities such as jumping or hiking
picture: The patient exhibits bilateral foot drop, with an inability to dorsiflex his feet. He has difficulty walking on his heels and has a noticeable steppage gait.
easing_factors: Rest, sitting, and elevation of the legs
past_history: The patient has a history of multiple ankle sprains and has undergone physical therapy for lower extremity strengthening and gait training.
medical_history: The patient has been diagnosed with Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease (CMT) type 1A, confirmed through genetic testing and electromyography (EMG).
medications: The patient is currently taking gabapentin for pain management and has tried physical therapy in the past to improve mobility and strength.
personal_history: The patient is married with two children and works full-time as an IT specialist. He reports difficulty with daily activities such as walking, climbing stairs, and participating in recreational activities.
imaging: The patient has undergone MRI and X-ray imaging, which revealed bilateral peroneal muscle atrophy and mild pes cavus deformity.
